i then looked at the date and i was like, wtf
my parents didnt even realise i wasnt around for 25 hours
when you live in parts of the world where it doesnt get dark in summer, it can confuse you as well when you wake up at 5 and don't know whether its morning or afternoon
its either always light or always dark
in my case, it was central europe, during summer

central europe has pretty normal day/night cycles
it just sucked when it got to 50*c ~
where the hell in Central europe is it 50 degrees?
in the place where i was in europe it was 48*c in the shade
kind've to the southern region of central europe, not southern europe tho
it was not too far away from czech republic
it wasnt in the balkans, but it did get to 48*c for 1-2 days then the rest was mid 40's
on the news they were saying 45-47 in the region
I'm not doubting you PZ, I was talking about germany
yeah in germany its extremely rare
in 2018 it reached above 50 in sicily
I remember in 2018 I came back from London where they had the hottest summer ever, back to germany where it was a solid 5 degrees hotter still
on the news it was reported as "dont leave the house due to dangerous hot weather"
yeah but in the Uk its the humidity thats gay
30 here in the Uk (i live in the uk so ik) it was tropical levels of humidity aka VERY bad
I don't think its that bad, it seems to me that the UK can't handle the heat
people are walking around in shorts atm when its 5*c outside so yes
the heat happened when i went on holiday to central europe
The dude with the winter jacket just had morning shift
there were reports in italy at the time that there was a government action to make sure everyone was hydrated (giving free bottles of water to EVERYONE)
yeah pretty much if you don't have air conditioning
which most of Europe doesn't have
no one in europe has AC tbh (very rarely LUL)
in the UK the houses are made more for colder weather/rain... in summer the older houses are fucked. i live in a house atm which was built post-ww1 so its not that bad
Yeah, here old would be like 70s
vicotrian houses are great for the atmosphere of british cities, but they're probably shit for the environment

the houses in the uk that you see that are made from bricks, ATTACHED (2 houses together to like 50 in a row). in the uk they "refurbish" the inside and call it a day... which is why 95% of housing in cities looks shit -_-
I think they got modernised over time, but old houses can only get up to a certain standard

most have or had a fireplace (modernised generally) there is always 1 staircase and up to 6 rooms per house... small rooms fyi with (my old house was victorian essentially) and had only 8 windows in total
u also get a small garden, some houses have gardens sized 10m^2
I live in a bottom floor of your standard flat building and I got a little lawn I have to mown
At least the flat building has shared lawnmower
My specific house (used to live in) had 2 toilets (only 1 had a shower), 1 living room, 1 small kitchen, 4 bedrooms (3-4 is usually the avg, some do go up to 6 tho)
I remember staying in a Hotel in england once where they had showers on the rooms but no toilet
yeah but it was my first time, was a bit surprised tbh
as long as there are no community showers it's fine
nah more like 4 families... in history i even learned that in Liverpool England there were 6 families (in total 18 people) living in 1 small victorian era house
still, 18 people with 4 rooms to share
guess if you didn't like your personal space invaded you just had to deal with it
the idea of personal space probably originated later tbh
the 1 thing i find funny in the Uk is that i drove by a house that looked dilapidated, or abandoned, a shithole essentially. but the guy had a 2015 Mustang (seen in 2016) GT infront of the house
yeah but there were no cars or public transport
having a decent house isleep, having a sick car realshit
